title: Applying to Oxford or Cambridge? Our expert guide to improving your chances
text:
If you wanted to design a system solely to bring out the conniving, anxious worst of the country’s most bookish teens, that system would be the Oxbridge admissions process. Armed with their AS levels or equivalent, the students currently undergoing this process must now prepare their application for either Oxford or Cambridge.

The first thing to know about this stage is that you can’t pick both. Between them, Oxford and Cambridge have existed for 17 centuries, and they’re not going to let you, an applicant who has existed for 17 years, play them off against each other.

So you’ll have to choose between them, which sometimes depends on which course you’re doing, and at the same time you’ll have to choose a college. There are vast colleges, cramped colleges, rich colleges, poor colleges, sporty colleges, studious colleges, beautiful colleges, ugly colleges, colleges which claim to no longer be posh, colleges which claim to be the friendliest or most fun or most supportive. 54 of them take undergraduates, and that’s not even counting Oxford’s six permanent private halls, which are smaller but similar.

The Telegraph has attempted to make as useful a comparison as possible between the colleges, ranking them on financial assets, academic performance, lifestyle and accommodation as part of our guide to applying to Oxford or Cambridge universities. Start here, and use the guide to work out which colleges offer the subjects you’re interested in, and which of those colleges best suit your priorities.
